text: When an intrusive thought appears, I notice it as a signal from my mind, not a real threat.
During moments of doubt, I pause and breathe before my body reacts with urgency.
When I feel the pull to check or repeat something, I notice the urge without following it immediately.
I let intrusive thoughts feel like urgent warnings that demand immediate action.
When uncertainty rises, I stay present and let the feeling pass without needing to fix it.
I recognize when my mind is looping on the same thought, and I choose to redirect my attention.
When I sense the urge to arrange or organize things perfectly, I notice the pressure and choose flexibility instead.
I let fear of contamination or harm drive me into repeated checking or cleaning rituals.
When my body feels tense from anxiety, I breathe slowly and ground myself instead of reacting to the sensation.
I see when my mind is exaggerating a small concern into a major threat, and I choose a simpler interpretation.
When I notice the pattern of thought leading to compulsion, I interrupt it early by staying still.
I let perfectionist demands control my actions and drain my time without questioning them.
When a disturbing image or idea appears, I label it as mental noise and let it drift away.
I recognize when my brain is sending false alarms, and I respond with calm instead of urgency.
When I feel the need to count or repeat actions, I notice the compulsion and choose to stop after one attempt.
I let rituals and routines become rigid rules that I must follow exactly, even when they cause stress.
When I sense the cycle starting—thought, anxiety, urge—I pause and observe it instead of reacting.
I notice when my mind is searching for certainty, and I choose to tolerate the uncertainty instead.
When I feel the pull to seek reassurance or check again, I recognize it as the pattern and resist the urge.
I let intrusive thoughts feel like personal failures or signs that something is wrong with me.
